reviews.author: Weewee
reviews.title: Essential Course for All LIFS majors
reviews.comment_content:
Midterm: (taught by Banfield)

Composition of Cells
How to study Cells
The Organization of Cellular Genomes
The structure of eukaryotic chromosomes
Biological membranes
Protein targeting and transport


Finals: (taught by Guo)

Aerobic respiration (focusing on oxidative phosphorylation)
The Nucleus
Vesicular traffic, secretion, and endocytosis
Cellular homeostasis
The Cytoskeleton and cell movement
Cellular communication
Cell division
Sexual reproduction
Extracellular Matrix
Cell communities, tissues, and organs
Stem cells and cancer


For topics on midterm, the material learnt from LIFS1902 could be slightly useful, especially the part about cellular genomes. Thus, it is recommended to review what you have learnt in LIFS1902.

Although LIFS1902 is not a prerequisite for this course, you would be a fool to believe HKUST on this. This course is very content-heavy and relies both on understanding and memorization in order to get a good grade.

You can see that the topics covered in Finals is much greater than that of Midterms, so it is highly recommended to make your own notes as early as possible, or you would be overwhelmed by the shear amount of content.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Banfield really likes to use long complicated words to get his ideas across. He often shows off his English proficiency with advanced grammatical techniques that are redundant altogether. As a native English speaker, I find it cumbersome when listening to his lectures. Banfield really likes to go off on tangents which you actually need to take note of, as everything he says would be included in the midterm.

Guo is a lot more direct with his wording, being clear and concise. He makes great use of his powerpoint slides, and rarely says anything beyond it. This makes his lecture notes much more valuable during revision.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm: 35% (made by Banfield)
Final: 65% (made by Guo)

My scores:
Midterm: 56/75
Final: 79.5/91
Grade: A
reviews.comment_workload: Preparing for midterm is OK for a normal LIFS course. Preparing for final is hell.

reviews.author: yoshi
reviews.comment_content:
Banfield:
Introduction to Cell Biology
The Composition of Cells
How do we study cells?
Organizations of Eukaryotic Genomes
Structure of Eukaryotic Chromosomes
Biological Membranes
How cells target proteins to membranes?

Teaches before the midterm (around 1/3 of the course)
The content that is taught by Banfield is a lot more difficult to study for as it is not just about memorization, but rather understanding what the bigger picture and the main idea is. He expects students to be able to apply what he taught in an unfamiliar scenario.

Guo:
How cells generate energy
The Nucleus
Vesicular traffic, secretion, and endocytosis
Mechanism of cellular homeostasis
Cytoskeleton and cell movement
Mechanisms of cellular communication
Cell Division & Sexual Reproduction
The extracellular matrix
Cell communities and the formation of tissues and organs and apoptosis
Stem cells and cancer

Teaches after the midterm (around 2/3 of the course)
the exams are non-cumulative (but there is an overlap of some of the content)
The content taught by Guo is a lot heavier than that of Banfield as Guo teaches for more than half of the semester. Hence there is a lot to memorize and understand. The tricky part of Guo's examination was the section where the multiple-choice has multiple answers.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Personally, I thought the teaching was great. I learned a lot from the professors in this course.

Banfield: There is a lot of extra information that he likes to include in his lectures (as he tends to go off topic occasionally). He does manage to get the point across though. His English is quite proficient and so it does take a while to get used to his teaching style, nothing too difficult though. His powerpoints are quite useless on their own, so it's definitely recommended to take notes on whatever he says in class.

Guo: Very straightforward and goes straight to the point. His powerpoints are extremely organized with objectives and summaries at the beginning & the end. It was very easy to follow because he used a lot of amazing diagrams from the textbook, and if there was a difficult concept, he would go over it two or three times. The powerpoint was quite detailed on its own, but there were occasions where he would say something important that wouldn't be mentioned in the powerpoint, so it is still important to take notes (especially when the slide only shows a diagram and he explains the process in class).
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm Exam (Exam I) 35% (Banfield)
Final Exam (Exam II) 65% (Guo)

Not entirely sure how they graded us. Heard that Banfield distributes the grades based on the performance of the whole class (not a strict percentage of how many students get As and how many get Bs). Not really sure about Guo.
reviews.comment_workload: There are no extra assignments or quizzes or anything. Just study for the midterm and the final. The content was manageable to study for.

reviews.author: letmegohome
reviews.title: Good teaching, but mt is hard...
reviews.comment_content:
(A lot of)Basic cell biology stuff.
I didn't choose Lifs as my major, and I don't think it's clever to take this course if you were a year 1 student, or you are not going to study life science in the future... which means I am a total sb...
But as far as I know, many yr 1 students took this course and got a nice grade, so I guess it really depends.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Banfield's lectures are pretty interesting, but Guo's content is better organized.
Both are great professors.
reviews.comment_grading:
Banfield's part is hard... for the midterm I got 41/75, and I don't think going through his ppt helped, since there were few words and mostly pictures in it...
Guo's part is much easier and his ppt is way more organized and clear. Got 81 out of 91 in final, which accounts for 65% of the final grade.
Final grade: B+
reviews.comment_workload: No hw, but you need to revise lots of stuff...

reviews.author: Diya A.
reviews.title: Cell biology
reviews.comment_content: Wide coverage of content. Starts off with techniques in biochem (very basic) and then dives into several different aspects like structure and function of the cell and sub-cellular organelles; from genes to proteins; membrane and cytoskeleton; cell communication and cell signaling; cell cycle and programmed cell death.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Amazing teachers! Banfield keeps the class engaged with his wit and sarcasm and welcomes questions from students. However, his slides aren't generally parallel with what he speaks so one might feel lost.

Professor Guo focuses on critical thinking from students- shows a lot of images and animations and asks students high order applicative questions for example- what technique would the researcher use to test this? A lot of in-class quizzes to check for understanding (not graded)
reviews.comment_grading:
In the online system, we mainly had MCQs and some short questions (labelling, identifying, understanding data).
Good scoring class.
reviews.comment_workload: There are a lot of topics covered and are crucial for understanding further topics in this field. One might feel there is too much to learn but once understood, everything flows like a story book.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Banfield is one of the worse instructors who likes to brag about his biological knowledge by using complicated terms, which he never explained and gives minor spoken presentations (none of the verbal information is found in his slides). Please take note and research the vocal terms and information, as it may be seen in midterm questions. Moreover, he skipped one lecture -how do we study cells due to lack of time but proceeded to include damn many questions in the midterms ==.

Guo on the other side, explains every slide he has and every term he uses not to complicate students. Guo is passionate about biological research and gives students insights into the research field. He is even kind enough to hold zoom QNA sessions every week. Overall, he did an excellent job of ensuring his materials were well-understood and inspiring students to participate in research.
reviews.comment_grading:
I believe the grading was quite good.
-Midterm -
Materials for midterms are just A-Levels / previous LIFS courses information added with some new information. However, the questions are hard and some answers can only be found in Banfield's verbal information
My score 55
Mean 49

-Finals-
The materials are very hard with complicated mechanisms - especially cell signaling processes oh god
However, if you memorise and understand the slides fully (you will perform better if you pay attention to some information emphasized by Guo), you will be able to answer the questions.

Our final scores were not provided

Letter grade : A
reviews.comment_workload: No workload; make sure you finish the lectures. Understand and memorise the materials for midterms and finals.

Overall:
The course is divided into two parts by the two exams and taught by two different professors with similar style in teaching. The course is mainly lectures with little Q&A sections for any related questions. The two professors are both opened to any questions and try their best in answering all of them. reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Banfield is terrible. He has no accent and his English is good, which should be a good thing. But as he keeps saying unnecessary parenthesis and keep speaking superfast, it seems as if he is showing off his English. He is also good at making simple things more difficult to understand and make you more confused than not asking. He pauses in the middle of the class to answer some questions asked by some students, which is quite disturbing sometimes. His slildes are also in a mess, with few knowledge and mostly pictures displayed in a very inorganized way. I saw some previous students saying that it is because his lectures are organized to demonstrate processes of solving questions, which is important scientific training for students aiming for research. I really can't agree. I strongly recommend you  read corresponding chapters in the textbook if you want to get good grade in the midterm, which is designed by Banfield. He already taught in a very chaotic way and still he tested quite a number of things not covered in his lectures.
On the contrary, although professor GUO has some accent, he explained things clearly and in detail. He asked some questions to guide students along each topic and cover related experimental methods adopted by scientists under each topic. His ppt is also clear and organized in a logical way. He finishes one powerpoint each lecture, divide each lecture into several parts and gives a few minutes's break during the class. He is very willing to answer students' questions after the lecture and gives one or two polling questions each class. However, I still recommend you read the textbook after the lecture to have a better understanding of the topic. (Textbooks always display the knowledge in a more organized way, and this may help you better clarify?) I prefer Prof.GUO's teaching style.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Banfield's teaching is, indeed, quite disastrous. I once did not believe his course reviews but ended up finding out 'His train of thought is like five trains coming at the same time' is the most accurate description I can possibly find. He always explains simple stuff in complicated manners, confusing us and also sometimes himself. Plus his slides are predominantly diagrams, making understanding even harder.

On the contrary, Prof. Guo is a decent lecturer. Though with accents, he is able to organize & deliver his content in a very structured and interconnected manner. Intuitive explanations such as 'any cell response that involves gene expression and or duplication will be a slower response' are also provided. He also asks many questions during lessons and points out many significant details that really allow the incorporation of concepts.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm (35%)

Me: 64/75, High:71, Mean: Around 52 SD: ~10 (Since the exact mean &SD is not disclosed and I calculated it based on all disclosed scores)

I can say I did not do extremely well in a midterm. I simply had no idea why some of you can get 70+ under Prof. Banfield's teaching and his confusing questions (Probably by studying the textbook or taking other courses?) My estimation is I was in the top 12% of the class.

Final (65%)

The total score was 85, with (if I recall correctly) 70 single-choice MCQs and 5 short questions. Originally there was an essay question, but Prof Guo kindly offered to remove it.

The final exam score was not disclosed. My estimation of my score is about 80+ (Since it is an online semester so I marked all the questions I am uncertain about on my draft papers and confirmed the answers after the exam)

Eventually got an A+. Prof Guo's final really saved my grade.

One tip for preparing for the final is to interconnect everything you have learned. For instance, compare treadmilling of actin filaments with the dynamic instability of microtubules. Or extract and summarize all cell processes that either (1) Involve GTP (2) Involve ATP (3) Involve phosphorylation (kinase) (4) Involve ubiquitin etc.

This is because the questions spanned through multiple chapters and often dig into seemingly unimportant details. I'll say that even if you cheat and have all PPT slides beside you, it is not likely that you can retrieve all these information accurately from the sea of content. Hence: Understand, memorize and connect!!
reviews.comment_workload:
No assignment so the work schedule is quite flexible. But if you want good grades then you definitely need to invest your time & effort.

For Prof. Banfield's part, I attended every single lecture and revise once per week. Not very helpful I'll say. Textbooks serve you better than his lectures.

For Prof Guo's part, I skipped almost all lectures and only hopped in last minute to screenshot his end-of-lecture quiz questions (not graded and not counted for participation, but will likely appear in the final exam). I would stock his lecture videos on the same topic and finish them in a marathon.

I think this approach was more helpful since I could pause whenever I feel confused, take notes, google, summarize and then proceed with a solid grasp of previous content. Takes about 2-3 hours per week in going through lecture videos, and I will take an extra 2-3 hours in revising the content.
